facts: The case originates from the anti-Sikh riots in Delhi following the assassination of Prime Minister Indira Gandhi on 31.10.1984.
Specifically relates to incidents of violence, arson, and murder in the Sultanpuri area of Delhi between 01.11.1984 and 04.11.1984.
FIR No. 416/1984 was registered at P.S. Sultanpuri regarding the killing of Surjit Singh, husband of complainant/witness Jagdish Kaur.
Initial investigations by Delhi Police did not name Sajjan Kumar; charge sheets were filed against other individuals who were eventually acquitted.
Several commissions and committees (Marwah, Misra, Kapur-Mittal, Jain-Aggarwal, Nanavati) investigated the riots over the years.
The Justice Nanavati Commission of Inquiry, in its report submitted in 2005, found credible evidence against Sajjan Kumar and others, recommending legal action.
Based on the Nanavati Commission report, the Government directed the Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) to conduct further investigation.
CBI recorded statements of witnesses, including Jagdish Kaur, Nirpreet Kaur, and Jagsher Singh, who implicated Sajjan Kumar in instigating and participating in the mob violence.
CBI filed charge sheets against Sajjan Kumar and others for various offences related to the riots in the Sultanpuri area.

The Trial Court (Additional Sessions Judge, Delhi), after considering the materials submitted by the CBI, ordered framing of charges against Sajjan Kumar and co-accused under multiple IPC sections on 17.12.2009.
Sajjan Kumar challenged the Trial Court's order before the Delhi High Court.
The Delhi High Court dismissed Sajjan Kumar's petition and upheld the Trial Court's order framing charges on 19.07.2010.
Sajjan Kumar appealed the High Court's decision to the Supreme Court of India.
The core issue before the Supreme Court was whether a prima facie case and 'grave suspicion' existed based on the materials on record to justify the framing of charges under Sections 227/228 CrPC.
ipc_sections: Section 153A (Promoting enmity between different groups on grounds of religion, race, etc.)
Section 295 (Injuring or defiling place of worship with intent to insult the religion of any class)
Section 427 (Mischief causing damage to the amount of fifty rupees)
Section 436 (Mischief by fire or explosive substance with intent to destroy house, etc.)
Section 449 (House-trespass in order to commit offence punishable with death)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Sufficient material exists on record raising grave suspicion against the accused, justifying the framing of charges. The standard at this stage is prima facie satisfaction, not proof beyond reasonable doubt.
precedents: Union of India v. Prafulla Kumar Samal (1979) 3 SCC 4
State of Maharashtra v. Som Nath Thapa (1996) 4 SCC 659
State of M.P. v. S.B. Johari (2000) 2 SCC 57
State of Orissa v. Debendra Nath Padhi (2005) 1 SCC 568
elements: Existence of witness statements (Jagdish Kaur, Nirpreet Kaur, etc.) implicating the accused.
Statements alleging accused instigated mobs, participated in violence.
Material gathered through official inquiries (Nanavati Commission) and CBI investigation.
Low threshold ('grave suspicion') for framing charges under CrPC S. 228.

counter_arguments.loophole: Significant delay in recording key witness statements specifically implicating Sajjan Kumar, casting doubt on reliability.
supporting_precedents: State of A.P. v. M. Madhusudhan Rao (2008) 15 SCC 582
Ganesh Bhavan Patel v. State of Maharashtra (1978) 4 SCC 371
Harbeer Singh vs Sheeshpal Singh (2016) 16 SCC 418 (on delay & credibility)

counter_arguments.loophole: Witness statements are allegedly improvements/contradictory to earlier statements or lack thereof; potentially politically motivated.
supporting_precedents: Kalyan Kumar Gogoi v. Ashutosh Agnihotri (2011) 2 SCC 532 (on assessing evidence quality)
Lallu Manjhi v. State of Jharkhand (2003) 2 SCC 401 (on scrutiny of interested witnesses)
State of U.P. v. M.K. Anthony (1985) 1 SCC 505 (on how courts treat discrepancies)

prosecution_arguments.argument: A prima facie case of criminal conspiracy (S. 120B) is made out from the circumstances, including the accused's alleged presence, instigation, and the organized nature of the attacks.
precedents: State (NCT of Delhi) v. Navjot Sandhu @ Afsan Guru (2005) 11 SCC 600
Kehar Singh v. State (Delhi Admn.) (1988) 3 SCC 609
Firozuddin Basheeruddin v. State of Kerala (2001) 7 SCC 596
elements: Accused's alleged role in directing/instigating mobs.
Systematic targeting of a specific community.
Circumstantial evidence pointing towards a common design.

counter_arguments.loophole: No direct evidence of agreement for conspiracy; inference drawn from weak/delayed statements.
supporting_precedents: State of Kerala v. P. Sugathan (2000) 8 SCC 203
V.C. Shukla v. State (Delhi Admn.) (1980) Supp SCC 92
Esher Singh v. State of A.P. (2004) 11 SCC 585 (need for conclusive proof of agreement)

prosecution_arguments.argument: Vicarious liability under Section 149 IPC is attracted prima facie, as the accused was allegedly part of an unlawful assembly sharing a common object to commit violence against the Sikh community.
precedents: Muniappan v. State of Tamil Nadu (1981) 3 SCC 11
Lalji v. State of U.P. (1989) 1 SCC 437
Bhudeo Mandal v. State of Bihar (1981) 2 SCC 755
elements: Offences committed in prosecution of the common object.

counter_arguments.loophole: Mere presence (if proven) is insufficient; specific evidence of shared common object by the accused at the time is weak.
supporting_precedents: Roy Fernandes v. State of Goa (2012) 3 SCC 221
Baladin v. State of U.P. AIR 1956 SC 181
Mizaji v. State of U.P. AIR 1959 SC 572 (on proving common object)

defense_arguments.argument: Inordinate and unexplained delay in naming the accused/recording statements renders the prosecution case weak and unreliable, failing to meet the 'grave suspicion' test.
edge_cases: Evidentiary value of statements recorded decades after the incident.
Impact of multiple prior investigations/inquiries not implicating the accused.
Potential for memory lapse, tutoring, or political influence over time.
precedents: State of A.P. v. M. Madhusudhan Rao (2008) 15 SCC 582
Ganesh Bhavan Patel v. State of Maharashtra (1978) 4 SCC 371
State of Orissa vs. Mr. Brahmananda Nanda (2016) CriLJ 1716 (Orissa HC, on delay)

defense_arguments.argument: Witness statements forming the basis of charges are contradictory, improved versions, and lack independent corroboration, making them insufficient for framing charges.
edge_cases: Admissibility and weight of statements made before Commissions of Inquiry vs. statements under S.161 CrPC.
Credibility assessment at the charge stage.
Identification of the accused in a chaotic riot situation after many years.
precedents: Kalyan Kumar Gogoi v. Ashutosh Agnihotri (2011) 2 SCC 532
Lallu Manjhi v. State of Jharkhand (2003) 2 SCC 401
Vadivelu Thevar v. State of Madras AIR 1957 SC 614

defense_arguments.argument: The material on record, viewed objectively, does not disclose a prima facie case or raise 'grave suspicion' against the accused, warranting discharge under Section 227 CrPC.
edge_cases: Scope of court's power under S.227 CrPC to sift evidence.
Whether the High Court failed to properly exercise its revisional jurisdiction.
precedents: P. Vijayan v. State of Kerala (2010) 2 SCC 398
Dilawar Balu Kurane v. State of Maharashtra (2002) 2 SCC 135
Niranjan Singh Karam Singh Punjabi v. Jitendra Bhimraj Bijja (1990) 4 SCC 76

judgment.outcome: Appeal Dismissed. The Supreme Court upheld the orders of the Trial Court and High Court framing charges against Sajjan Kumar.
reasoning: The standard for framing charges under Section 228 CrPC requires only a prima facie assessment of whether the material on record discloses 'grave suspicion' against the accused.
The court is not required to meticulously weigh evidence or conduct a mini-trial at the charge stage.
The probative value of witness statements (including those allegedly delayed or contradictory) is a matter for trial, not for determination at the charge stage.
The statements of witnesses like Jagdish Kaur, Nirpreet Kaur, etc., recorded by the CBI, along with findings of the Nanavati Commission, constitute sufficient material to raise grave suspicion.
Issues of delay, witness reliability, contradictions, and political motivation are defenses to be raised and tested during the trial through cross-examination.
The court cannot assume that the witness statements are unreliable at this preliminary stage.
The High Court correctly applied the settled legal principles regarding the framing of charges and did not err in upholding the Trial Court's order.
Arguments regarding the merits of the evidence, delay, and witness credibility cannot be accepted for quashing charges at this stage.
